After careful monitoring, the patient's condition stabilized and the patient was discharged with instructions to continue with his oral medication. The patient expired a month later due to an unrelated condition.  In conclusion, this summary describes the diagnosis, treatment, and monitoring of a patient with Diastolic Heart Failure Acute. Discharge Summary:  Mr. Smith, a 64-year-old male with a medical history significant for hypertension and diastolic heart failure, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure. He presented with symptoms of dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, and pedal edema.  During his hospital stay, Mr. Smith underwent a complete evaluation, including an echocardiogram that showed diastolic dysfunction with grade 2 mitral regurgitation. His chest x-ray revealed signs of pulmonary edema and a number of his laboratory tests were abnormal, including elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels.  Mr. Smith was started on a regimen of furosemide (Lasix) and metoprolol for management of his congestive heart failure (CHF) and systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF). He underwent diuresis and received appliximab for mitral valve regurgitation. His fluid overload improved with diuretics, leading to disordered electrolytes. His BNP levels decreased, and he experienced improved diastolic function.  Mr. Smith showed improvement on his physical exam, with resolution of his dyspnea and decreased pedal edema. He was discharged home after the completion of his treatment, with a prescription for metoprolol and furosemide. He was advised to follow-up with his cardiologist in one week.  Unfortunately, Mr. Smith experienced progressive symptoms at home and was readmitted to the hospital, where he expired due to his chronic and progressive condition of diastolic heart failure.  Overall, Mr. Smith's hospital course was marked by the management of his acute diastolic heart failure with diuretics and medications to improve systolic congestive heart failure and mitral valve regurgitation. Despite these interventions, his progressive condition ultimately led to his unfortunate demise.

Patient was admitted with symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF) with a diagnosis of diastolic heart failure (DHF). The patient was promptly started on diuretic therapy with Furosemide (Lasix) to treat volume overload, resulting in increased diuresis and completed relief from symptoms. An echocardiogram revealed regurgitation and a disordered diastolic condition. To manage cardiac output, Metoprolol was initiated on low doses which were gradually increased under close monitoring. Despite these interventions, the patient's condition continued to worsen, and treatment was escalated to include the use of Appl (Angiotensin II receptor blocker). However, the patient eventually expired due to severe progression of diastolic and systolic heart failure (SCHF). In summary, the patient presented with acute DHF with significant volume overload and regurgitation. The patient was treated with Furosemide and Metoprolol to achieve diuresis and manage cardiac output, respectively. Despite these efforts, the patient's DHF condition continued to worsen and expired.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted with the diagnosis of Diastolic Heart Failure, acute. During the hospitalization, their condition was closely monitored and evaluated. The patient was found to have completed the course of treatment as prescribed by the attending physician.  The patient was treated with Lasix (Furosemide) to alleviate the CHF (Congestive Heart Failure) and SCHF (Systolic Congestive Heart Failure). The treatment resulted in diuresis, reducing the fluid overload by gradually removing excess fluid from the body. The patient was also prescribed Appl (Aldosterone antagonist) to prevent cardiac remodelling and Metoprolol to lower the heart rate and treat the disordered heart condition. Overall, the medication regimen was effective in managing the diastolic regurgitation.  The patient was discharged after improvement in their clinical condition. The patient's vital parameters were stable at the time of discharge, and there were no complications during the hospital stay.  The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician regularly to ensure that their medical condition is appropriately monitored. The patient was advised to continue the medications as prescribed and to make necessary lifestyle adjustments recommended by the physician.   Unfortunately, the patient expired after leaving the hospital. The cause of death was not immediately available.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure (DHF) as evidenced by shortness of breath, fatigue and peripheral edema. The patient’s clinical course was complicated by systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF) and mitral regurgitation (MR). During the hospitalization, the patient received diuretic therapy and the condition was managed with a combination of medications including metoprolol and furosemide (Lasix) due to fluid volume overload. The patient’s diuresis was completed and the overload was resolved. Unfortunately, the patient’s condition was further complicated by a disordered and severe regurgitation, which was identified as the underlying cause of the DHF. Despite vigorous medical management, the patient expired due to complications of the regurgitation and SCHF. The patient’s family was notified and palliative care assistance was provided to them.

Patient:  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure. The patient had a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) with systolic and diastolic dysfunction. The patients had a history of multiple episodes of shortness of breath and peripheral edema in the past. The patient was a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia. The patient was on medications including enalapril, furosemide, and metoprolol.  Admission:  Upon admission, the patient was experiencing shortness of breath, tachypnea, and pedal edema. The patient had BNP levels of 600 pg/mL. An echocardiogram was done, which revealed severe mitral regurgitation, mild mitral stenosis, and diastolic dysfunction. The left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was 40%, and the left ventricular diastolic function was Grade III. The patient had moderate pulmonary hypertension. The patient was started on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), lasix 40 mg twice daily, and metoprolol tartrate 12.5 mg twice daily. The patient's fluid intake was restricted, and the patient was monitored closely for diuresis.  Progress:  Over the next two days, the patient's pedal edema improved, and the diuresis was completed. The patient's BNP level decreased to 350 pg/mL. The patient's CPAP was discontinued, and the patient was started on regular diet as the patient's fluid overload decreased. The patient was planned for discharge with regular follow-up with the cardiologist.  Discharge:  The patient was discharged on lasix 40 mg once daily with a plan to taper off the medication gradually. The patient was advised to monitor fluid intake and body weight regularly. The patient was instructed to follow a low salt diet and avoid strenuous activity. The patient was advised to continue with the medications as prescribed and to follow-up with the cardiologist in 2 weeks. The patient's final diagnosis was diastolic heart failure with moderate pulmonary hypertension secondary to mitral regurgitation and mitral stenosis.   Unfortunately, the patient expired due to the disordered condition secondary to diastolic heart failure.

Discharge Summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of Diastolic heart failure, acute. During the hospital stay, several tests were completed revealing that the patient had a condition known as Schf, caused by a disordered diastolic filling pattern. The condition resulted in diastolic overload, which in turn led to an increase in pulmonary pressures, and consequently, difficulty breathing. The patient was treated with furosemide (Lasix) and Metoprolol to reduce the overload and regulate heart rhythm.  During the hospital stay, the patient's diuresis was closely monitored, and a number of diuretics were administered, including Furosemide. The diuretics helped in reducing the fluid overload and resulted in an improvement in the patient's Hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. However, despite these interventions, the patient still had moderate Mitral regurgitation.  The patient was eventually discharged after showing signs of clinical improvement. The patient was counselled on the importance of adhering to the prescribed medication regimen even after discharge, especially for the Metoprolol to prevent the recurrence of the symptoms, and required to attend regular follow-up appointments with the cardiologist.  However, the patient's condition later deteriorated, resulting in an untimely expiration that may have been related to the Mitral regurgitation.

History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient had previously been diagnosed with Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) with reduced ejection fraction six months ago.  Clinical Course: During hospitalization, the patient was diagnosed with Diastolic Heart Failure (DHF) with evidence of diastolic dysfunction and left ventricular hypertrophy on an echocardiogram. The patient was initially started on diuretics (Furosemide/Lasix), and a regimen of lisinopril, aspirin, and metoprolol were added. The patient's fluid overload improved as diuresis completed. The patient was closely monitored for any signs of volume and electrolyte abnormalities.  During the hospital stay, the patient developed acute CHF with symptoms of pulmonary overload and diuretic resistance. There was an associated mitral regurgitation with an increase in the number of PVCs. Appropriate changes in medications were made, and diuresis was assisted using intravenous Bumetanide and spironolactone for management of Schizophrenia (SCHF).  Despite the medical interventions, the patient's condition remained disordered, and the patient expired.  Discharge Diagnosis: 1. Diastolic Heart Failure (DHF), Acute 2. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF), Acute 3. Mitral Regurgitation 4. Schizophrenia (SCHF)  Recommendations: The patient was diagnosed with Diastolic Heart Failure (DHF), Acute and was managed with medications and diuretics which resulted in diuresis. However, despite the interventions, the patient's symptoms were exacerbated and led to acute CHF with concomitant mitral regurgitation. The patient expired while still in the hospital due to poor response to treatment.  In conclusion, the patient had a complex medical history that included multiple comorbidities. Despite the attention to detail in the patient's management, achieving effective management remained challenging.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure. The patient had completed treatment with lasix and was diagnosed with severe systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF) with mild diastolic dysfunction. The patient had significant regurgitation and an elevated number of appl (atrial pressure). Metoprolol was added to control the patient's heart rate and prevent further overload. Furosemide was used to induce diuresis and treat fluid overload. Despite these treatments, the patient expired due to the severe regurgitation and the patient's disordered heart condition.

Patient: [Patient name hidden for privacy]  Medical Record Number: [MR Number hidden for privacy]  Discharge Summary:  This is a discharge summary for the patient diagnosed with Diastolic heart failure, acute. Upon admission, the patient was found to have a history of SCHF and CHF with diastolic dysfunction. The patient presented with symptoms of shortness of breath, generalized weakness, and fatigue. The patient had a normal sinus rhythm on ECG.  The patient was treated with a diuresis regimen, which included Furosemide (Lasix) 40mg, completed each day for a total of 5 days. This regimen resulted in adequate diuresis, and the patient's condition improved significantly. The patient was able to tolerate the diuresis regimen without any adverse side effects.  The patient was also prescribed Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg daily, to regulate the heart rate and blood pressure. This medication was well-tolerated without any significant changes in the patient's condition.  During hospitalization, an echocardiogram revealed mild mitral regurgitation that was not deemed the causative factor for this admission. The patient also had a number of other health conditions, including disordered sleep due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension.  The patient had a CHF overload condition when they first arrived, but the treatment reduced the overload significantly. The patient was eventually able to stabilize and was discharged home on Furosemide, Metoprolol Tartrate, and strict iced-fluid intake. The family was advised to monitor the patient's fluid and salt intake and watch for any signs of CHF (shortness of breath, swelling in feet and ankle, coughing).  Unfortunately, the patient expired at home two weeks after discharge due to an unrelated cause.

Patient Name: [redacted] Date of Admission: [redacted] Date of Discharge: [redacted]  Diagnosis: Diastolic heart failure, acute  Clinical History: The patient was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, difficulty in breathing, and cough for one week. The patient was diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute, and was kept under observation in the hospital. The patient had a past medical history of hypertension and was on medication for the same.   Treatment: Upon admission, the patient was started on medications including metoprolol and furosemide. Lasix was also completed for the patient. The patient was diagnosed with systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF) with regurgitation and was treated with furosemide to manage the condition.   The patient was also closely monitored for fluid overload and diuresis. The patient's number of appl was monitored throughout the treatment, and the patient was given furosemide to manage the fluid retention.   Outcome: Despite the treatment, the patient's condition worsened, and the patient unfortunately expired due to the disordered heart function and insufficient response to the medications.   Conclusion: The patient was diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute, and was treated through a regimen that included metoprolol and furosemide. Lasix was also completed, while the patient was monitored for fluid overload, diuresis, number appl, and systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF) with regurgitation condition. Despite the treatment, the patient's condition did not improve, and the patient expired due to the disordered heart function.

Patient X was a 68-year-old male diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute. The clinical presentation was consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF) and systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF). The echocardiogram showed severe diastolic dysfunction with diastolic dysfunction marked by E/A reversal, increased E wave amplitude, and evidence of regurgitation. The patient was started on Metoprolol and completed a course of Furosemide (Lasix) for diuresis.  Despite diuresis, the patient continued to show evidence of congestion and overload, and there was evidence of regurgitation in the left atrium. The patient's condition was further complicated by disordered diastolic function and a number of other medical comorbidities. Despite aggressive management and use of multiple medications, the patient eventually expired due to complications from his heart failure.   In summary, Patient X was diagnosed with acute diastolic heart failure and treated with a combination of diuretics, beta-blockers, and other supportive measures. However, the condition remained severe, complicated and eventually led to the patient's demise.

Patient Name: [Insert Name] Date of Discharge: [Insert Date]  Diagnosis: Diastolic heart failure, acute  Medical History: The patient had a history of congestive heart failure (CHF) and was previously diagnosed with systolic heart failure (SCHF) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). The patient's medical history also included aortic regurgitation and a disordered diastolic condition.  Hospital Course: The patient presented to the hospital with shortness of breath and fatigue. Upon evaluation, the patient was diagnosed with acute diastolic heart failure with an ejection fraction greater than 50%. The patient was treated with Lasix (furosemide), and diuresis was promptly initiated to relieve volume overload. A number of medications were also administered, including metoprolol, to reduce the workload of the heart.  Throughout the admission, the patient's heart failure continued to worsen, and there was increased pulmonary congestion. The patient expired despite our best efforts to manage her symptoms.   Summary: The patient was diagnosed with acute diastolic heart failure, a condition characterized by impaired relaxation of the heart during diastole, and the inability of the ventricles to fill with blood properly. The patient had a medical history of CHF, LVH, aortic regurgitation, and a disordered diastolic condition. The patient was treated with Lasix (furosemide) and other medications to reduce the workload of the heart, and diuresis was initiated to relieve volume overload. Despite our best efforts to manage her symptoms, the patient unfortunately expired.

Patient X was admitted to the hospital with symptoms indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF). Upon further evaluation and testing, the patient was diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute. The patient was started on medications including Metoprolol to manage their condition.  Throughout the hospital stay, the patient's condition remained guarded. Diuretics, such as Furosemide and Lasix, were administered to relieve fluid overload, and diuresis was regularly monitored. While there was some reduction in fluid overload, the patient's condition was complicated by regurgitation of fluid intake.  Despite aggressive management of the patient's condition, the patient expired secondary to their disordered cardiac function. With symptoms of Shortness of Breath, Swelling (edema) in the feet and legs, and difficulty breathing at rest or lying flat, this patient was considered to have a very serious condition.  Overall, the applicable number of medications was successfully completed, and the appropriate management was attempted to relieve the patient's symptoms. However, the patient's deteriorating condition caused difficulties in treatment leading to the unfortunate conclusion.

Discharge Summary:  The patient, diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF) and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of systolic congestive heart failure (SCHF) and hypertension.  Upon admission, an echocardiogram was performed, which revealed moderate to severe mitral regurgitation with diastolic dysfunction. The patient was started on metoprolol to control the heart rate and improve diastolic function.  The patient was also started on diuretics, including furosemide (Lasix), to manage fluid overload and promote diuresis. There was a significant improvement in the patient's condition as diuresis was completed, and the fluid overload subsided.  However, the patient continued to experience symptoms of CHF, including dyspnea and edema. The patient's medication regimen was adjusted, and another echocardiogram was performed, which showed persistent mitral regurgitation.  The patient was managed with medications, including metoprolol and furosemide, and the patient's condition improved marginally. However, the patient's regurgitation condition remained disordered, and despite the best efforts of the medical team, the patient expired.  The patient's family has been informed, and condolences have been offered. The medical team has initiated a postmortem review to identify ways to improve diagnosis and care for patients with diastolic heart failure, acute.

This patient presented to the hospital with symptoms consistent with diastolic heart failure. The patient was diagnosed with acute diastolic heart failure and was started on various medications including metoprolol and furosemide. The patient's condition was complicated by regurgitation and systolic heart failure (SCHF) leading to fluid overload.  The patient received treatment including diuresis with furosemide (Lasix) completing a number of diuresis procedures to alleviate fluid buildup. After this process, the patient's condition improved and they were able to maintain a regular heart beat. However, regurgitation persisted, indicating a disordered condition that unfortunately expired the patient.   In summary, this patient presented with acute diastolic heart failure, complicated by regurgitation and SCHF leading to fluid overload. Treatment included diuresis with furosemide (Lasix), metoprolol, and other medications. Despite the efforts, the patient unfortunately expired due to the disordered condition.

This discharge summary is for a patient who has been diagnosed with diastolic heart failure, acute. The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), which included shortness of breath, fatigue, and fluid overload. After a thorough evaluation, the patient was diagnosed with diastolic heart failure due to a condition called regurgitation.  During the hospital stay, the patient was treated with diuretics such as furosemide and lasix to manage fluid overload and promote diuresis. Additionally, the patient was started on metoprolol to manage their condition, and completed their course of medication while at the hospital.  At the time of discharge, the patient was clinically stable, with improved symptoms of CHF. However, they were advised to monitor their condition closely and report any changes to their healthcare provider. The patient was given a number of instructions regarding their treatment, including:  - Avoiding excessive salt intake - Monitoring their blood pressure - Taking their prescription medication as directed - Following up with their healthcare provider in two weeks  The patient was also advised to follow a low-sodium diet, and continue to manage their condition with medication. The patient's condition was considered disordered, and they were advised to continue seeking medical attention if they experienced any worsening of symptoms.  Unfortunately, the patient eventually expired due to complications related to their condition. Despite the best efforts of the healthcare team, this patient succumbed to the effects of diastolic heart failure, resulting in their passing.

Patient: [Name] Age/Sex: [Age]/[Sex] Date of Admission: [Date of Admission] Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]  Medical Diagnosis: - Diastolic heart failure, acute - Regurgitation condition  Medical History: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of shortness of breath and generalized weakness. The patient had a history of diastolic heart failure, with other comorbidities such as SCHF (systolic congestive heart failure) and CHF (congestive heart failure). The patient was on Metoprolol and Furosemide for this condition.  Clinical Findings: The patient was found to have an overload of fluid, which was consistent with a diastolic heart failure diagnosis. The patient's condition was furthered by the presence of regurgitation, which was observed in the echocardiography report.  Treatment: The patient was treated with Lasix and Furosemide to improve diuresis and decrease fluid overload. The patient's condition was monitored, and a number of diuresis were completed. Regurgitation was controlled with appropriate medications and monitoring.  Outcome: Despite the initial disordered heart function, the patient was eventually stabilized during hospitalization, and there was a gradual improvement in the condition. However, unfortunately, the patient expired due to complications that arose during the course of treatment.  Conclusion: The patient was treated appropriately for the diagnosis of acute diastolic heart failure and regurgitation condition with the use of Metoprolol, Furosemide, Lasix, and other medications. However, despite the best efforts of the medical team, the patient expired due to complications.

Patient Name: John Doe ID Number: 123456  Discharge Summary: The patient, John Doe, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of Diastolic Heart Failure (DHF) due to acute SCHF and CHF with regurgitation. The patient presented with shortness of breath, cough, and ankle swelling. Admission labs showed a BNP level of 800pg/mL, indicating cardiac overload.  During the hospital stay, the patient was started on Furosemide (Lasix) for diuresis and completed a number of sessions with Appl'd metoprolol to manage their condition. The patient's diuresis was closely monitored, and the Furosemide dose was adjusted accordingly to maintain fluid balance.  The patient experienced some complications during their hospital stay due to their disordered heart function. The patient had regurgitation from their heart, which led to decreased cardiac output, increasing their risk of pulmonary edema. In order to manage the regurgitation, the patient was started on Metoprolol and underwent echocardiography during their hospital stay.  After a few days in hospital, the patient showed improvement in their condition. The patient's diuresis was adequate, and clinical examination showed no apparent overload. The patient was subsequently discharged on Furosemide (Lasix) and Metoprolol to continue managing their condition at home.  The patient was advised to continue their medications as prescribed and keep up with their regular follow-up appointments to monitor their heart function. In the event of any new or worsening symptoms, the patient was advised to seek medical attention immediately.  The patient expired some time afterwards due to their heart condition.
